referenceFunction.generalComment:
This cumulative energy demand (CED) LCI method was created to support the application of the CED method to FEDEFL-adapted LCI data FLCAC. All heating values are per the FEDEFL method, and the list of external references is found on the EPA FEDEFL GitHub at: https://github.com/USEPA/Federal-LCA-Commons-Elementary-Flow-List/tree/master/fedelemflowlist/input.
For example, the uranium heating value of 500 GJ/kg is based on a 45,000 MWd/t burn-up of 3.5% enriched U in a light water reactor (LWR). This factor is for 'Natural Uranium, in LWR' per the World-Nuclear Association at: https://www.world-nuclear.org/information-library/facts-and-figures/heat-values-of-various-fuels.aspx.
This CED method is based on the categorization scheme used in Frischknecht et al. (2003) found in the ecoinvent report "Implementation of Life Cycle Impact Assessment Methods".
Note that:
* The method is based on higher heating values (HHV). * Wood (_"Wood"_, _"Hardwood"_, _"Softwood"_) and biomass (_"Biomass"_) flows from nature are included in this methodology but must be examined in the context of each specific LCI to flag and account for the energy of material resources due to the frequent use of wood and biomass as material feedstocks. * Similarly, the onus of separating the energy of material use of fossil resources is left to the practitioner in the context of each specific application. NOTE: There are exchange comments in USLCI plastic resins datasets where crude oil & natural gas inputs are intended for material use. * Normalization is based on tonne oil equivalents based on the global average factor from the World-nuclear Association at: https://www.world-nuclear.org/information-library/facts-and-figures/heat-values-of-various-fuels.aspx. One tonne of oil equivalent (toe) is equal to 41.868 GJ. Each impact category is given the weighting factor 1 (i.e., are weighted equally). * Other adaptations: The technosphere flow 'Energy, unspecified' is included in the 'Non-renewable, fossil' category as this flow is present in many datasets of USLCI with the exchange comment ("Represents other fossil energy inputs"). * Not included: Energy from hydrogen from water resources; Energy, recovered; Steam from waste incineration.
